awd_titl_txt: Dynamics of the Low-Frequency Variability of the Kuroshio Current System
awd_abstract_narration:
9911268
The investigator advances the hypothesis that an important source of 
decadal variability for the Kuroshio lies in the interaction of the 
Kuroshio with the inertial recirculation to its immediate south.  
He argues that this interaction is a possible mechanism for the rapid 
transitions between two alternative persistent equilibria, one in which 
the Kuroshio path is relatively straight as it flows past Japan and one 
in which it develops a quasistationary southward meander.  The 
investigator proposes to test this hypothesis with a simplified 
numerical model of the north-west Pacific, a low vertical resolution 
version of MICOM.  In particular, he will examine the potential 
vorticity budget of the time varying Kuroshio/inertial recirculation 
system.  Experiments will also be made to test the influence of surface 
buoyancy fluxes over the recirculation gyre on the evolution of that gyre. 
The region of the Pacific concerned and its dynamical counterpart in the 
North Atlantic are the locations of some of the largest air-sea heat 
exchanges seen outside the tropics.
